articles.headline: Facing Money Gap, Hillary Clinton Slowly Warms to ‘Super PAC’ Gifts
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign, with a focus on campaign finance reform, has seemed reluctant to change its tactics even as Republicans draw big donations.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign, with a focus on campaign finance reform, has seemed reluctant to change its tactics even as Republicans draw big donations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton recently spent four days straight scurrying across the Western United States, mingling for hours at a time with hundreds of Democratic donors from the Rockies to Portland, Ore., from Southern California to the southern tip of Texas, and everywhere seeking the maximum primary campaign contribution allowed by law: $2,700.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Many Black Lawyers Navigate a Rocky, Lonely Road to Partner
articles.snippet: Only a relative handful of African-American lawyers persevere on the years-long path to joining a law firm’s lucrative leadership circle.
articles.abstract: Only a relative handful of African-American lawyers persevere on the years-long path to joining a law firm’s lucrative leadership circle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jimmie L. McMillian’s path to partnership in an Indianapolis law firm might seem unexceptional — except for a few telling details.

articles.headline: Carly Fiorina’s Business Record: Not So Sterling
articles.snippet: Mrs. Fiorina is rising in the polls as she runs for the Republican candidacy on the strength of her track record as a businesswoman. The trouble is, it’s not a good record.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Fiorina is rising in the polls as she runs for the Republican candidacy on the strength of her track record as a businesswoman. The trouble is, it’s not a good record.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I come from a world outside of politics, where track records and accomplishments count.”

articles.headline: Work Policies May Be Kinder, but Brutal Competition Isn’t
articles.snippet: Top-tier employers may be changing their official policies in a nod to work-life balance, but brutal competition remains an inescapable component of workers’ daily lives.
articles.abstract: Top-tier employers may be changing their official policies in a nod to work-life balance, but brutal competition remains an inescapable component of workers’ daily lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, in Silicon Valley, across the legal profession and the corporate world, a growing chorus of companies are singing the praises of a kinder workplace, announcing policies like generous maternity leave at Netflix, and Goldman Sachs’s rule against investment-banking analysts working on Saturdays.

articles.headline: Inflation Robs Russians of Buying Power
articles.snippet: The country is experiencing the first sustained decline in living standards in the 15 years since President Vladimir V. Putin came to power.
articles.abstract: The country is experiencing the first sustained decline in living standards in the 15 years since President Vladimir V. Putin came to power.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMENSKOYE, Russia — A basic barometer of economic activity in this tidy town south of Moscow is the pirozhok, a small pie filled with cabbage and meat that is a staple of the Russian diet.

articles.headline: China’s Turbulent Markets Keep Still-Eager Investors Guessing
articles.snippet: In the face of growing doubts, some investors are still looking for investment opportunities in China.
articles.abstract: In the face of growing doubts, some investors are still looking for investment opportunities in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: As China’s once-staid currency suddenly dropped sharply last week, Wall Street began sniffing around for a way to profit.
